description: From Anglo-Norman redunder, Middle French redonder, and their source, Latin rēdundō, from rē + undō (“surge”), from unda (“a wave”).

entries.meaning: A coming back, as an effect or consequence; a return.

verbs.description: redound (third-person singular simple present redounds, present participle redounding, simple past and past participle redounded)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To swell up (of water, waves etc.); to overflow, to surge (of bodily fluids). [14th–19th c.]
(intransitive) To contribute to an advantage or disadvantage for someone or something. [from 15th c.]
examples: The honour done to our religion ultimately redounds to God, the author of it.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To contribute to  the honour, shame etc. of a person or organisation. [from 15th c.]
examples: One thing about the 'John McCain-didn't-sleep-with-a-lobbyist' story redounds to the New York Times' credit.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To reflect (honour, shame etc.) to or onto someone. [from 15th c.]
(intransitive) To attach, come back, accrue to someone; to reflect back on or upon someone (of honour, shame etc.). [from 16th c.]
examples: His infamous behaviour only redounded back upon him when he was caught.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To arise from or out of something. [from 16th c.]
(intransitive, of a wave, flood, etc.) To roll back; to be sent or driven back.
